On Mon, 30 Aug 2004 19:01:31 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> Wow that is really cool!  So this network is trying to determine if
> something is an A?  

Yeah.  The network basically has five outputs, four which control its
movement and a fifth for affinity.  The output for the affinity neuron
basically indicates its confidence that this is the letter it's been
evolved to identify.  So when shown an "A" it should output a value
close to 1; when shown any other letter, such as a "Y", it should
output values close to 0.

> I don't think I've ever seen a video like that.
> It's very interesting.  How complex is the network?

Since the eye input resolution is 7x7, there are 49 input nodes for
the visual input.  We started as NEAT does, with no input nodes, fully
connected, so the initial topology has about 300 genes.  We used a
blended approach with a bias toward pruning, so I believe this network
is about 280 genes, with about 20 hidden nodes.

> Another thing I'm wondering is if the fact that the eye always zooms
> into the upper left corner means it is basing its final decision
> only on the appearance of that small part of the letter?  That is,
> is memory (i.e. recurrent connections) important at all?  If you cut
> out the recurrent connections what would it do?

Well, we can do a run where we disable recurrency.  Not having
performed these experiments, I'd guess that it would function much the
same.  I don't think recurrency is doing much here.

One thing I failed to note, but should probabably be fairly
clear...the left window of the movie shows a top-level view of the
behavior of the eye.  The line in the circle indicates the eye's
orientation, and it's actually upside down and fully zoomed out at
step 1.  The right window is what the eye is seeing as it moves
around.  You can see that for an "A" it always zooms in on the upper
portion and you see exactly the same pattern in that window by the end
of its steps.

So we think that initially the eye is just identifying the upper left
bound of whatever symbol is in its visual field, and as it zooms in it
tries to identify the inverted V at the top of the "A".    I think
it's basing its affinity output based on whether or not it finds that
single feature.

We're pretty happy with the results so far, but the behavior is pretty
simplistic.  If there were samples that varied in two areas of the
image, so that it needed to analyze two parts of the image to make a
correct identification, this sort of behavior obviously wouldn't do.

Derek
